description:
You might try to run this through terminal: /opt/cisco/anyconnect/bin/vpnui

Then you will be able to see the error message.  In my case, libpangox was not found.  This can be fixed by: dnf install pangox-compat
Does not work and can not be removed either.
This software does not work at all and I met difficulties when trying to remove it!
summary: Does not work and refuses to be removed

description: This software did not work until I tried Zhe's workaround. I'm on Fedora 25.
summary: Did not work until I tried work around

description: I was not able to get this working by using the default install script. However, on Arch I installed the package 'networkmanager-openconnect' and was able to connect to my VPN. This could possibly work on other distros as well.

But I managed to make it work thanks to Zhe's comment. 

"You might try to run this through terminal: /opt/cisco/anyconnect/bin/vpnui

Then you will be able to see the error message. In my case, libpangox was not found. This can be fixed by: dnf install pangox-compat "

Not something I'd expect to have to do to make something just run.

summary: Great App but one needs to install `dnf install pangox-compat`

description:
Did not work for me at all.
Additionally, I could not uninstall the software via the GUI, which was annoying.
To uninstall, follow the instructions here: https://askubuntu.com/questions/119213/uninstall-cisco-vpn-client-anyconnect
summary: did not work and did not want to be uninstalled

description:
It worked well, but I no longer have use of it. For your information, the uninstall took quite a while to figure out, since the remove button is broken (files are in a protected area and you can't remove without being superuser). It also shows as "not installed" for some reason to apt and dpkg. So after a hunting around my computer, I finally figured it out.

1. Run AnyConnect
2. Open Task Manager
3. Locate the AC process. Mine was labelled vpnui. It will likely have the Cisco symbol by it, if that helps.
4. Right click it, and press properties. Look for the "command line" field to see the it's file location.
5. In terminal, navigate to the location by using cd. Mine was located under /opt/cisco, which had the subfolders anyconnect and vpn.
6. In the parent folder (the one right above cisco, so /opt for me), do sudo rm -r cisco/. This command will put you in superuser mode, and recursively remove all files and folders in the directory (deletes everything in /opt/cisco).

Please make sure you are using to correct folder, and not just copying what I am saying. Confirm uninstall by searching for any connect. It should no longer appear Of course, you COULD use this method for other store apps that present the same problem, but do be careful. Deleting the wrong thing can break your system, especially when in superuser mode. It is ok for AC though.
